MiramoXML.P: Customization
Customizing the com.miramo.mmpdf plugin

The com.miramo.mmpdf plugin is intended to cover most formatting requirements, but in some cases it may be necessary to create a custom plugin which overrides or adds to some of the features supported by the standard plugin. If so, do not modify the files in the default MiramoPDF DITA-OT plugin installation folder (DITA-OT3.x\plugins\com.miramo.mmpdf), because these files will be overwritten when you install a new version of the MiramoPDF DITA-OT plugin Create a custom MiramoPDF DITA-OT plugin instead.
This chapter explains how to create a new custom plugin com.abc.mmpdf for a company called abc, which supports a transformation type abc-mmpdf, as shown here:

Creating a custom MiramoPDF DITA-OT plugin using oXygenXML Author/Editor
This topic describes how to use the MiramoPDF 2.0.0- generate new plugin transformation scenario in oXygenXML Author/Editor to create a new custom plugin.
The plugin is for a company called abc, and results in a new transtype abc-mmpdf'.

ParaGroup.P: In oXygenXML Author/Editor, choose OptionsImport Transformation Scenarios.
Navigate to your MiramoPDF installation folder, for example C:\Program Files\Oxygen XML Editor 23\frameworks\dita\DITA-OT3.x\plugins\com.miramo.mmpdf\integration\oxygen .
Select MiramoPDF-generate-plugin.scenarios and click Open.
In the Import scenarios dialog, select Project Options and click Import.
Create or open any DITA file.
For example you can open a DITA file in the following samples folder:
Click the Configure Transformation Scenario button.
In the Configure Transformation Scenarios dialog, select the MiramoPDF - generate new plugin transformation scenario and click Edit.
Click the Parameters tab and change the plugin-name and transtype parameters, as shown in the example below.
A transtype is a new transformation type with any new custom parameters that are supported. In this case, the transtype is the Miramo transformation with customizations done in a custom.xsl file.
Click OK and then Apply associated to run the transformation scenario.
In your DITA-OT installation folder, you will now find your custom com.miramo.abc-mmpdf plugin folder where you can make the necessary customizations in the cfg\xsl\custom.xsl file.
Choose OptionsImport Transformation Scenarios.
Navigate to your newly created, custom MiramoPDF folder.
For example: C:\Program Files\Oxygen XML Editor 23\frameworks\dita\DITA-OT3.x\plugins\com.abc.mmpdf .
Select the .scenarios file, for example com.miramo.flow-mmpdf.scenarios, and click Open.
In the Import scenarios dialog, select Project Options and click Import.
Click the Configure Transformation Scenario button again.

P.P: Your new custom transformation scenario is now ready for use.

ParaGroup.P: You can click Apply associated to test your custom transformation scenario.

MiramoXML.P: Manually creating a new custom plugin
This topic describes how to create a new custom plugin if you don't have access to oXygenXML Author/Editor.
The plugin is for a company called abc, and results in a new transtype abc-mmpdf'.
To do this, copy the plugins/com.miramo.mmpdf/com.example.my-mmpdf folder to plugins/com.abc.mmpdf
Then edit the following files in the new com.abc.mmpdf:

ParaGroup.P: plugin.xml
conductor.xml
build.xml

MiramoXML.P: Replace all occurrences of com.example.my-mmpdf with com.abc.mmpdf
Replace all occurrences of my-mmpdf with abc-mmpdf
Modify xsl/dita2miramo.xsl, cfg/xsl/custom.xsl, cfg/strings/langlist.xml, cfg/strings/*.xml as required
Run the DITA-OT integration process
The ant target 'dita2abc-mmpdf' will now be available
Running the DITA-OT integration tool
Next, install the new com.example.my-mmpdf plugin by running the DITA-OT ant integration tool as enabled by your CMS or authoring tool, or using one of the commands below.
For oXygen, see .
For standalone DITA-OT installations, use:
ant -f integrator.xml
or use the dita command:
dita-ot-dir/bin/dita --install
This will register the new transformation type abc-mmpdf which you can use in place of the mmpdf transfomation type. It will also add a new ant target dita2abc-mmpdf.
The next stage is to modify the files in the plugins/com.miramo.mmpdf folder.
com.abc.abc-mmpdf files and folders
The com.example.my-mmpdf plugin includes the following files and folders:
<dita-ot-installdir>/plugins/com.abc.mmpdf
Source for the custom com.abc.mmpdf plugin:
plugin.xml
Configuration file for the com.abc.mmpdf plugin which supports a new transformation type abc-mmpdf
conductor.xml
Imports local build.xml
build.xml
Contains the dita2abc-mmpdf target, applied by the abc-mmpdf transformation type.
xsl/dita2miramo.xsl
Top level stylesheet - do not edit
cfg/strings/langlist.xml
Language configuration file including a list of files containing localization strings
cfg/strings/*.xml
Miramo specific localization strings, supplied in addition to the standard DITA-OT localization strings (including those in pdf2)
cfg/xsl/custom.xsl
Modify this file to add xsl stylesheet template match modifications; included by xsl/dita2miramo.xsl
cfg/xsl/functionstubs.xsl
Modify this file to add new variable definitions or document wide metadata. Included by cfg/xsl/custom.xsl
Setting default build parameter values

To set default build parameter values applicable to all publications built with the new custom transtype, modify the custom init target in the build.xml file located in the custom plugin folder. These values are defaults and can be overridden as needed by setting ant build parameters, for example by changing the MiramoPDF - com.abc.mmpdf
The default init target overrides the mmpdf:localization-strings.dir and mmpdf:mfd.dir properties as shown below:

<target name="abc-mmpdf-init">
<!-- add build parameter overrides here.
Default to using local cfg/strings folder for localization-strings -->
<property name="this.plugin.dir" value="${dita.plugin.com.miramo.abc-mmpdf.dir}"/>
<property name="mmpdf:localization-strings.dir" value="${dita.plugin.com.miramo.abc-mmpdf.dir}${file.separator}cfg${file.separator}strings"/>
<property name="mmpdf:mfd.dir" value="${dita.plugin.com.miramo.abc-mmpdf.dir}${file.separator}mmtemplates"/>
</target>

Here's an example of setting the default value for mmpdf:fontPath to reference a folder containing the custom fonts which are necessary for producing PDFs using the abc-mmpdf transformation type. In the example, the company specific fonts are located in a fonts subfolder of the com.abc.mmpdf plugin folder:

<target name="abc-mmpdf-init">
<!-- add build parameter overrides here.
Default to using local cfg/strings folder for localization-strings -->
<property name="this.plugin.dir" value="${dita.plugin.com.miramo.abc-mmpdf.dir}"/>
<property name="mmpdf:localization-strings.dir" value="${dita.plugin.com.miramo.abc-mmpdf.dir}${file.separator}cfg${file.separator}strings"/>
<property name="mmpdf:mfd.dir" value="${dita.plugin.com.miramo.abc-mmpdf.dir}${file.separator}mmtemplates"/>
<!-- Company specific fonts are located in the fonts subfolder of this plugin -->
<property name="mmpdf:fontPath" value="${dita.plugin.com.miramo.abc-mmpdf.dir}${file.separator}fonts"/>
</target>
Customizing the com.abc.mmpdf using XSLT

Edit the cfg/xsl/custom.xsl stylesheet to add <xsl:template> matches to achieve the required mapping from DITA elements and attributes to MiramoXML elements and attributes. (See the mmComposer Reference Guide for a detailed description of the MiramoXML file format).

<xsl:template>s added here may either override or add to the <xsl:template>s defined in the default DITA to MiramoXML stylesheets located in the com.miramo.mmpdf/xsl folder, for example map2miramo.xsl, topic2miramo.xsl and utilities.xsl.
Here is a simple example where a <note> element with @type set to 'other' is mapped to a 'callout' ParaDef:

The slightly more complex example is shown below, which adds support for an <entry> element @outputclass value of 'subheading' to allow insertion of subheading rows within a table. The customization below is used to produce this document, an example of the resulting subheadings is shown in :
<!-- Support for <entry> @outputclass='subhead': provide overrides for standard
makeOneRow (handles keep with next) and mm:cellAttributesFromOutputClass (applies
custom table cell formatting
MiramoXML attribute names and values are specified in the mmComposer Reference Guide
-->
<!-- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -->
<!-- Override makeOneRow utility to check for <entry> @outputclass=subheading to set keepWithNext property
to prevent orphaned subheadings -->
<xsl:template name="makeOneRow">
<xsl:param name="type"/>
<!-- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -->
<Row type="{$type}">
<xsl:call-template name="addRowAttributes"/>
<xsl:if test="*[@outputclass='subheading']">
<xsl:attribute name="withNext">Y</xsl:attribute>
</xsl:if>
<xsl:apply-templates/>
</Row>
</xsl:template>
<!-- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -->
<!-- Override mm:cellAttributesFromOutputClass utility to set paragraph format to tableHeader, switch off row shading and add ruling.
-->
<xsl:function name="mm:cellAttributesFromOutputClass" as="node()*">
<xsl:param name="outputclass" as="xs:string?"/>
<xsl:param name="node" as="node()"/>
<!-- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -->
<xsl:if test="contains($node/@outputclass, 'subheading')">
<xsl:attribute name="paraDef">tableHeader</xsl:attribute>
<xsl:attribute name="fillColor">none</xsl:attribute>
<xsl:attribute name="topRule">Very Thin</xsl:attribute>
<xsl:attribute name="bottomRule">Very Thin</xsl:attribute>
<xsl:attribute name="topMargin">8pt</xsl:attribute>
</xsl:if>
</xsl:function>
